bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Edwin C. Shaw, August 6, 1919

div1.p: Carter writes about the desirability of centralized medical relief and staffing for a possible city public health clinic.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Edwin C. Shaw, August 6, 1919
div1.opener:
Miscl
Proposed Polyclinic at
Akron, Ohio.
/LC
August 6, 1919.
Dr. Edwin C. Shaw,
533 Second National Building,
Akron, Ohio.
Dear Doctor Shaw:
div1.p:
In answer to your letter of August 1/19, received to-day,
I would say

(1) As to the desireability of the proposed Polyclinic:
There is no question as to the advantage of concentrating medical
relief into one place except (a) for towns so large that parts of
them are too distant from any one place for all people to conve-
niently come to it and (b) where there is some industrial, or
other, establishment, which requires a special place of relief ad-
jacent to itself. If neither of these conditions obtain at Akron,
a concentration of the different kinds of sick-relief is advisable--
possibly obstetrical relief may be an exception.

(2) As to the practicability of the proposed Polyclinic, I
do not know enough as to the conditions a+ Akron to answer.

The use of a clinical clerk for the routine history and a
stenographer for the (physician's) special questioning and the find-
ings of his examinations will greatly lessen the time of the medi-
cal examinations. In general physicians are willing to give a mod-
erate amount of their time for strictly professional work of the
kind that (as I understand) you propose at this Polyclinic, without
-2-
charge. That matter, however, is to be settled locally. If you
take in pay patients, physicians should be paid. The Manager of
the institution, naturally, should be paid.

The addition of a dispensary where medicines are furnished
and hospital accomodations for such patients as need them will pre-
vent the work from being limited to diagnosis. If it be impracti-
cable--it may well be--to concentrate the hospital relief of Akron
at one place, it may be practicable to make arrangements for such
hospitals as you have to receive as patients from the Polyclinic
such as need hospital relief.

The concentration of the services of the different medical and
surgical specialists at one place should be an unending advantage to
the sic and, I am sure, an advantage to the physicians as well.
This is what is arrived at at the large hospitals of the larger cities.

With best wishes for the success of whatever plan you agree on,
I remain
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Md.
